data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to set up reverse DNS.**
data.summary_suggestion: Configure reverse DNS for a dedicated IP address
data.description_suggestion: Creates a new reverse DNS configuration for a dedicated IP address. Requires the IP address and sending domain as inputs. Twilio SendGrid will provide an A Record that must be added to your domain's DNS records. Once the A Record is verified, the reverse DNS record is automatically generated. Returns the created reverse DNS record with verification status. This operation enables mailbox providers to verify your email sender identity through reverse DNS lookup.
data.reasoning: Original summary and description are too generic and lack critical context. Missing details about: what inputs are required (IP address, domain), what the operation returns, the verification workflow, and why this matters (mailbox provider verification). Added domain-specific terminology and workflow context for better AI agent understanding of when and how to use this operation.

message: Operation 'GetReverseDns' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_output_details, missing_context. Summary is clear and appropriate. Description is too minimal and lacks details about what is returned. Enhanced description explains the return value and use cases for AI agents to understand when to call this operation versus the list operation.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a reverse DNS record.**

You can retrieve the IDs associated with all your reverse DNS records using the "Retrieve all reverse DNS records" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a specific reverse DNS record by its ID. Returns the complete reverse DNS configuration including the IP address, domain, verification status, and validation results. Use this operation to check the current state of a reverse DNS record, including whether the A Record has been verified and the reverse DNS is active. You can discover available record IDs using the ListReverseDns operation.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and appropriate. Description is too minimal and lacks details about what is returned. Missing information about the response structure (verification status, validation results) and the purpose of retrieving individual records. Enhanced description explains the return value and use cases for AI agents to understand when to call this operation versus the list operation.

message: Operation 'DeleteReverseDns' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_side_effects. Summary is clear and appropriate. Description mentions the 204 status code but lacks critical side effects information. data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a reverse DNS record.**

A call to this endpoint will respond with a 204 status code if the deletion was successful.

You can retrieve the IDs associated with all your reverse DNS records using the "Retrieve all reverse DNS records" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: Deletes a reverse DNS record by its ID. Returns HTTP 204 on successful deletion with no response body. This operation removes the reverse DNS configuration for the specified IP address, which will stop mailbox providers from being able to verify your sender identity through reverse DNS lookup for that IP. The associated dedicated IP address will no longer have reverse DNS configured. Ensure you intend to remove this configuration before proceeding.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and appropriate. Description mentions the 204 status code but lacks critical side effects information. Missing context about what happens after deletion (reverse DNS verification stops, mailbox provider verification fails). Enhanced description explains the consequences of deletion and adds a cautionary note to help AI agents understand the impact of this destructive operation.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to validate a reverse DNS record.**

Always check the `valid` property of the response's `validation_results.a_record` object. This field will indicate whether it was possible to validate the reverse DNS record. If the `validation_results.a_record.valid` is `false`, this indicates only that Twilio SendGrid could not determine the validity your reverse DNS record  it may still be valid.

If validity couldn't be determined, you can check the value of `validation_results.a_record.reason` to find out why.

You can retrieve the IDs associated with all your reverse DNS records using the "Retrieve all reverse DNS records" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: Validates the DNS configuration for a reverse DNS record by its ID. Performs verification checks on the A Record and reverse DNS settings. Returns validation results including the `validation_results.a_record.valid` boolean and a `reason` field explaining any validation failures. Note: A `valid` value of `false` indicates Twilio SendGrid could not verify the record, not necessarily that it is invalidthe DNS configuration may still be correct. Check the `reason` field for diagnostic details. Use this operation after adding the A Record to your domain's DNS to confirm proper configuration.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and appropriate. Description contains important validation logic but is poorly organized and lacks clarity about the operation's purpose and workflow. Missing context about when to call this operation (after DNS configuration) and what the response structure means. Reorganized to explain: what the operation does, what it returns, important caveats about the valid field, and when to use it. This helps AI agents understand the validation workflow and interpret results correctly.
